metadata.case_name: Petitioner v. Collector of Excise, Allahabad & Ors.

facts.text: Petitioner was a wholesale and retail dealer in tobacco at Banaras and owned a private bonded warehouse for tobacco and held licences for the same.
Petitioner's warehouse checked by Inspector Das who found irregularity, sealed warehouse on December 8, 1953, and took possession of registers and stock cards.
On December 22, 1953, 11 1/2 bags of kandi (stems of tobacco) found in petitioner's warehouse were removed by Inspector and stored elsewhere.
Petitioner made representations to Collector and correspondence passed.
On June 15, 1954, Collector issued show cause notice why penalty for contravention of Rules 151C and 226 of Central Excise Rules, 1944, and why bags of kandi confiscated.

Petitioner showed cause, Collector heard petitioner who filed written arguments; Collector found charges proved, ordered confiscation of bags, fine of Rs. 150 and duty in lieu, penalty of Rs. 2,000 under rr. 151C and 226.
Appeal to Central Board of Revenue dismissed as petitioner refused to deposit penalty of Rs. 2,000; revision to Central Board dismissed for same reason.
On July 29, 1954, Collector called upon petitioner to produce another surety as previous surety Mohammad Satar not prepared to act.
Petitioner furnished two bonds in Form B-4 and B-5 for Rs. 7,000 and Rs. 10,000 respectively.
Sum of Rs. 15,263-8-0 due from petitioner as excise duty; 373 Mds. of tobacco attached by Excise Department and sold by auction for Rs. 6,878-5-0, leaving balance of Rs. 8,385-3-0.
Petitioner filed civil suit in court of First Additional Civil Judge, Banaras, who issued ad-interim injunction restraining Department from recovering balance.
On January 25, 1956, Superintendent of Excise called upon petitioner to deposit cash security of Rs. 10,000 otherwise licence treated as cancelled under r. 181 of Central Excise Rules.
Petitioner demurred; as outstanding duty not paid, Deputy Collector ordered on February 13, 1956, that till deposit made, petitioner's licence shall remain inoperative.

Appeal against order to Central Board of Revenue dismissed; petition under Art. 226 in Punjab High Court dismissed; revision against Deputy Collector's order dismissed by Central Board on December 20, 1956.

legal_issues.text: Whether ss. 6 and 8 of the Act and Rules made thereunder were beyond legislative competence of Central legislature under Government of India Act, 1935.
Even if within competence, whether they impose excessive and unreasonable restraint on fundamental right under Art. 19(1)(g) and not saved by Art. 19(6).
Whether orders passed were ultra vires the Act and Rules.

petitioner_arguments.text: ss. 6 and 8 of the Act and Rules beyond legislative competence under 1935 Act as encroaches on items 27 and 29 of List II; pith and substance regulates trade/commerce though imposes excise duty.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Item 45 List I vs Items 27,29 List II Govt of India Act 1935; rr.140-148,150,171-181,215,226 Central Excise Rules; r.176 licence fee; r.181 revocation/suspension

petitioner_arguments.text: Restrictions unreasonable, not saved by Art.19(6): no procedure for notice, evidence, unbiased tribunal for penalties/confiscation.
Orders ultra vires: required deposit of penalty before appeal/revision; demanded fresh surety/cash security without authority.

court_reasoning.text: Pith and substance of Act is levy and collection of excise duty on tobacco under item 45 List I Govt of India Act 1935; regulations (licensing, warehousing, penalties) incidental and necessary for effective collection, even if trench on List II items 27,29.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Act is fiscal measure; rules track tobacco movement from growth to sale for duty realisation; licence fees form of taxation.

court_reasoning.text: Restrictions reasonable under Art.19(6): principles of natural justice followed (show cause, hearing); appeal/revision available and availed.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No breach of audi alteram partem.

court_reasoning.text: Orders not ultra vires: deposit condition for appeal not illegal; fresh security demanded valid under r.140 proviso as previous surety ceased.

holdings.text: Central Excises and Salt Act, 1944 and Rules within legislative competence under item 45 List I; incidental regulations valid.
Restrictions not unreasonable, saved by Art.19(6).
Impugned orders valid and not ultra vires.

outcome.summary: Court held Act and Rules within competence, restrictions reasonable, orders valid; petitioner's arguments rejected.

key_quotes.text: In every case where the legislative competence... it is necessary to examine the pith and substance of the Act and if the matter comes substantially within an item in the Central List it is not deemed to come within an entry in the Provincial list...
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: The Act was within the legislative competence of the Central legislature and although there may be certain matters otherwise within the legislative competence of the provincial legislature they are necessarily incidental to effective legislation...
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: If the tribunal is to act judicially it must conform to the principles of natural justice of audi alteram partem and there is no dispute that in the instant case there was no breach of this rule.
key_quotes.speaker: court
